data projects

World Energy Trilemma Index

about

The World Energy Trilemma Index is a quantification of the energy trilemma, defined as the triple challenge of providing secure, equitable and affordable, environmentally sustainable energy. Balancing these priorities is challenging but is also the foundation for the prosperity and competitiveness of individual countries.

The Trilemma is an energy policy pathfinding tool that relies upon historic data to assess historic past energy policy performance. The key data sources include International Energy Agency's World Energy Balances and Indicators, World Bank's Global Development Data, Joint Organisations Data Initiative's Oil and Gas database, and World Resources Institute's Climate Watch.

The Trilemma Index has been prepared annually since 2010 by the World Energy Council in partnership with global consultancy Oliver Wyman. It presents a comparative ranking of 127 countries’ energy systems, and provides an assessment of a country’s energy system performance, reflecting balance and robustness in the three dimensions.

The results are published annually during World Energy Week Live, a global conference that was held online in the last years due to the pandemic. The main output is a report that consists of a number of chapters that present changes in the Index as well as insights in long-term trends of energy systems. Country profiles presenting the results are available in an online tool and extended country profiles are shared with 80 member committees of the Council.

I have contributed to 2020 and 2021 reports, and throughout the whole project period with data processing, analysis and research, consulting as well as design and creation of infographics. I assessed and streamlined many of the project's processes, for example: verification and quality control of the calculations; management of the project's dozens of datasets; redesigning and automating extended country profiles.
